Sure enough, that paper is buried in my to-read pile.

>Agreed. Just genera=
lly - if a search is stuck then 'do something else'
>would seem to be good =
advice :)

Right. I'm trying to get a grip on what that something else to d=
o is :)

I'm sure I'll be back with plenty of questions as I get going on m=
y
proposals. Much thanks for the insights.


-Drew



On Fri, Mar 25, 2011 =
at 4:55 PM, Colin Green <colin.green1@...> wrote:
> On 25 March 2011 =
12:51, Drew Kirkpatrick <drew.kirkpatrick@...> wrote:
>>
>> Just curi=
ous as I've been thinking about this a bit lately (I'm new to NEAT stuff), =
as it
>> seems that the micro mutations you talk about, if I'm=A0interpreti=
ng=A0papers right, is one of
>> the reasons standard NEAT doesn't handle fr=
actured domain problems well. As you
>> say, it can't "get there from here"=
. It can't build enough structure and optimize it's
>> performance to find =
a better solution before that species dies out.
>
> Actually "fractured dom=
ains" wasn't a term I was aware of, however I
> just read this:
>
> =A0 Evo=
lving Neural Networks for Fractured Domains (2008), Nate Kohl
> and Risto M=
iikkulainen.
> =A0 http://nn.cs.utexas.edu/downloads/papers/kohl.gecco08.pd=
f
>
> So fractured domains =3D discontinuity. And yes I would say that's
> =
definitely a major problem with NEAT (not sure about HyperNEAT). I'm
> inte=
rested in their use of radial basis functions, which is something
> that ha=
s been mentioned before on this group but not something that
> I've looked =
into deeply.
>
>> Is this the problem you're looking to address here? Or ju=
st a method of escaping a local
>> maxima in fitness by allowing more radic=
al adjustments/growth to network topologies in
>> general?
>
> Well it's es=
sentially the same thing if discontinuity is the reason
> you're stuck - wh=
ich is very often the case I would say. Complex
> fitness lanscapes are alm=
sot by definition 'fractured' (As an exercise
> try and think up a complex =
landscape/domain that isnlt fractured).
>
>> One thing I was wondering abou=
t, and I haven't poked around to see if anyone has done
>> some research in=
to, is fiddling with the species die-off parameter. I was thinking it might=

>> be worth trying (if someone hasn't done it yet), is to remove the speci=
es die off if-hasn't-
>> improved-in X generations bit if no species fitnes=
s has improved in some specified
>> amount of generations.
>
> I wouldn't e=
xpect this to be a major issue where we are right now. If
> a species hasn'=
t improved in a long time then it's probability of
> improving in a further=
 equally long time is low. Evolutionary
> techniques constarined by computi=
ng resources are always a
> probabilities game - you try and spend your lim=
ited CPU time searching
> the areas of the space that have the highest prob=
abilities of yielding
> good solutions. This same argument sort of applies =
to the idea of
> increasing populations - from one perspective the size of =
the
> population is irrelevant as you can only evaluate some fixed number o=
f
> genomes per unit of time. The main effect of pop size is thus to
> prov=
ide a broader genetic base to drive genetic crossover and to keep
> an as d=
iverse as possible population of search points across the
> fitness landsca=
pe.
>
>
>> I think if you've sat with the same "champion" for a large numbe=
r of generations, it could
>> be worthwhile to do something radical, like g=
reatly increase mutations,
>
> Agreed. Just generally - if a search is stuc=
k then 'do something else'
> would seem to be good advice :)
>
>
>> I'm sur=
e someone has toyed with this at some point. I can always use another coupl=
e
>> hundred of pages of papers/dissertations to add to my "to-be-read" pil=
e going into my
>> thesis :)
>
>
> I think others have played with dynamic =
mutation rate. The problem I
> think is that there may not be any easy rout=
es out of a local maxima,
> increasing mutations will sample points a littl=
e further out than
> before but it's potentially clutching at straws in man=
y cases. The
> other way of looking at it is that the encoding space or the=
 fitness
> landscape (sort of teh same thing) could be changed such that th=
ere
> are easier routes to the good solutions - that's essentially what the=

> radial basis function paper above is doing - your nets can;' get there
>=
 from here, so use a different type of net.
>
> Colin
>
